Veronica Sawyer.Action: Maintains composure calmly after Heather McNamara disrupts her writing and addresses Heather's interruption directly and with clear attitude.
Submissively greets Heather Chandler despite the tense social environment and Heather's intimidating presence.
Reluctantly agrees to forge a mean note but admits she doesn't have anything against Martha
Latches onto the pen involuntarily, showing hesitation but still participates
Reluctantly agrees to forge a note in Kurt's handwriting despite personal objections to hurting Martha.
Shows hesitation and moral conflict but ultimately complies under Heather Chandler's pressure.
Acknowledges and remembers a social commitment she missed and apologizes sincerely to Betty Finn.
Gets distracted by an attractive figure and accidentally bumps into Betty Finn, causing minor embarrassment.
Compliments Courtney by saying 'You're beautiful' when she expresses a desire to give money to the poor.
Questions Heather Chandler about why they can't talk to different kinds of people, showing tolerance.
Submissively apologizes to Heather Chandler after being insulted.
Confronts Heather Chandler directly about her social reputation, showing willingness to challenge a dominant figure.
Uses sarcastic, clever language ('Pretend you're a missionary saving a colony of cootie victims') to influence Heather.
Attempts to moderate Heather Chandler's behavior by physically removing her from the group when Heather is being openly antagonistic.
Follows Heather Chandler despite feeling disturbed and hesitant, showing some reluctance but still going along with the plan.
Observes various social groups warily and notices details about people around her, indicating awareness and situational understanding.
Calls out 'Damn..' in frustration or surprise, indicating a momentary loss of composure.
Shakes her head with a half-smile at the Heathers' whining imitation, signaling awareness and subtle judgment.
Says 'A true friend's work is never done' before going to confront Heather Duke about her harmful behavior.
Gently suggests Heather Duke should see a doctor about her self-harm.
Defends Heather Duke against the rudeness of the other Heathers by telling her not to listen to them.
Jokes to Heather Duke about moving Holden Caulfield, showing wit and quick thinking.
Physically intervenes by sticking her finger in Heather Duke's mouth to stop her from speaking further.
Defends J.D. by saying he only used blanks and downplays the shooting incident with a giggle.
Responds to Heather Chandler about giving up on high school guys with a lighthearted 'Never say never.'
Encourages Heather Duke during a difficult shot, showing support and good judgment of the situation.
Misses her shot at the croquet game despite the pressure to perform well at a social event.
Smiles at J.D.'s coolness and engages in light, friendly banter.
Glares at Heather Chandler's interruption but then turns back to J.D.
Cleverly flirts with J.D. using humor and 7-11 jargon, showing social awareness and conversational skill.
Reads J.D.'s intentions and engages confidently despite Heather Chandler's interruption, maintaining composure and focus.
Demonstrates situational awareness by glaring at Heather Chandler's impatient horn but chooses to ignore it and stay engaged with J.D.
Comforts and affectionately interacts with J.D., showing physical closeness and gentle behavior.
Rejects and challenges J.D.'s lethal violent suggestions about Heather Chandler.
Makes a sarcastic, somewhat cold remark ('There's a big difference between the most popular girl... and dead sperm').
Suggests seeing Heather Chandler suffer to get back at her.
Warns J.D. against using dangerous Pine-Sol, showing concern for consequences.
Quietly shares insider knowledge about Heather skipping grandma's trip when hungover.
Argues against using an obviously suspicious poison drink and suggests a more subtle method (milk and orange juice).
Shows fear and hesitation when confronted with J.D.'s dangerous plan.
Takes control of the situation by physically taking the cup and mixing a less suspicious drink.
Mocks or trivializes the poisoning by joking about adding phlegm, demonstrating a wry but practical approach.
Irritates or dismisses J.D.'s jokes and keeps focus on the task at hand.
After the confrontation, methodically cleans up and organizes toxic containers, showing practicality and responsibility.
Asks J.D. if he has done this before, indicating quick thinking and situational awareness amidst a tense moment.
Smiles initially but then the smile dies when looking at Heather Chandler’s corpse, showing emotional vulnerability that may undercut confidence.
Acknowledges the suicide note with horror, then continues speaking, realizing her ability to create truths for a captive audience.
Solemnly puts on Heather's Swatch after it is tossed to her, showing respect and composure.
Responds with a queasily smile to the pupils' applause after speaking about Heather's realization on giving up power.
Stands up spooked after receiving the Swatch but composes herself.
Moves zombiesquely into the shower area after negative comments, showing withdrawal.
Takes off the soaked watch and disposes of it promptly.
Uses the remote control skillfully and decisively to mute and change channels during the TV interview.
Questions and challenges Courtney's statement on TV logically and assertively.
Expresses a desire for her high school to be a nice place and apologizes for sounding 'bitchy'.
Responds neutrally to Heather McNamara's question about her evening plans.
Mentions having something going with J.D. without further elaboration or enthusiasm.
Questions and challenges Courtney and Courtney's Friend about their gossip, indicating awareness and willingness to address rumors.
Appears dazed and confused after hearing crude gossip, and hands a clump of money to Peter without focus.
Makes a risky and provocative phone call to Kurt, confronting him directly about his fantasies and rumors.
Recognizes the similarity between the note and handwriting sample, and engages with J.D. critically about the note's language and tone.
Attempts to test the bullet that supposedly does not kill by aiming at a cat, showing poor judgment and lack of foresight.
Quickly accepts J.D.’s correction when told the bullet doesn’t work on small animals.
Engages in the investigation alongside J.D. with some playful but critical remarks (e.g., about Perrier water).
Giggling and joking with J.D. moments before violence
Smiles and giggles after missing shot at Kurt
Laughter abruptly stops; shows trembling and confusion after J.D. shoots Ram
Approaches Ram's body with visible shivers and realization of death
Instinctively shoots Kurt in a frightened, animalistic reaction
Tugs out the car lighter and savagely brands the palm of her hand as an impulsive reaction to guilt and stress.
Holds her hands over her ears and sings 'We're Off to See the Wizard' to block out J.D.'s relentless 'did-to' accusations, using distraction to avoid emotional manipulation.
Recognizes and verbally denies her true feelings about having wanted the victims dead, showing internal conflict and some self-awareness.
Allows J.D. to exert psychological dominance by repeatedly verbally harassing her and provoking her distress, demonstrating a lack of emotional control in the moment.
Agrees to appear on a newsmagazine show about the suicides, showing willingness to engage with serious topics.
Drinks vodka while talking on the phone and writing in her diary, showing emotional distress and possible impaired judgement.
Reflects thoughtfully in her diary about the impact of recent events on her peers and herself, demonstrating self-awareness and insight.
Expresses lack of fear about her boyfriend J.D.'s potential actions, indicating possible denial or underestimation of risk.
Hungover, stumbles down the hall, passively reads the announcement sign, then continues walking without engaging.
Fingers her bangs in an attempt at composure and steps into the cafeteria to join the students chanting, showing leadership and poise.
Responds to J.D. unzipping her dress by quickly breaking the spell and swinging her elbow into his stomach, asserting boundaries and reacting skillfully.
Disgusted by J.D.'s violent destruction of the TV image and expresses breakup.
Allows J.D. to playfully tackle her and shares a calm, intimate moment.
Admits vulnerability by saying 'I don't know how to talk to you.'
Genially lobbies Earl Frazier to get a 'sweet homeboy' for the TV show, chuckling and appearing friendly.
Genially lobbies Earl Frazier to secure a homeboy for the TV show, attempting to influence the project positively.
Sighs then plays croquet calmly, engages in casual conversation with Betty and Heather McNamara, and questions Heather Duke about responsibilities.
Criticizes Heather Duke for talking down to people and making fake notes.
Steps on her own croquet ball to prevent Heather Duke's move and correctly points out that it's not her turn.
Expresses self-deprecating comment 'Ich Luge bullets. I'm such a jerk' while tending to her burn.
Keeps calm and composed while joining Peter Dawson for the TV studio event, adapts quickly to social setting.
Feels mortified by Whitney James's mocking remarks about teen suicide and the privileged kids' complaints
Responds to bleak social commentary with a sympathetic but lightly expressed lament ('The world wants winners, I guess. Not people stained with loserness.')
Sickened and nauseated by the insensitivity and superficiality of the TV studio environment and discussion
Responds to Whitney James’s cynical remarks with a sharp, witty comment: 'The world wants winners, I guess. Not people stained with loserness.'
Is mortified and visibly upset by the social commentary and situation she is witnessing, showing emotional vulnerability.
Manages to maintain a light tone despite feeling flabbergasted, indicating some control over her emotions in a difficult scenario.
Becomes sickened and physically affected by the environment, ultimately going to throw up, suggesting a lack of emotional resilience in this context.
Bursts through the circle of handholding students, breaking the staged unity.
Quivers before breaking the ritual but does not engage in hostile actions.
Rips off her pink armband, symbolically rejecting the event's forced harmony.

Snaps off the TV in protest against a condescending program on teen suicide, criticizes how youth are patronized and ignored, and expresses desire to be treated like human beings rather than subjects.
Snaps off the TV to protest condescending media portrayal of youth suicide and critically comments on it.
Engages in a clear, articulate dialogue challenging her parents' oversimplified and sentimental views on youth issues.
Laughs half-bitterly at the irony of her mom's misunderstanding before shifting setting.
Leans against the wall with a melancholy smile and responds thoughtfully to Mom's comment, showing self-awareness.
Slaps Heather Duke in the face impulsively after a provocation.
Apologizes to Heather Duke after physical confrontation.
Rubs her bloodied feet on the ground, showing practical attention to her physical state.
Simultaneously moves into stunned kneeling position realizing who the caller is, showing quick awareness of the situation.
Listens quietly and observes Heather McNamara’s distress and confession, appears passive, focusing on note-taking instead of intervening.
Punches Heather McNamara's face to disrupt her suicide attempt, then talks her down with pointed but caring remarks.
Physically jumps on the spilled pills impulsively after the punch.
Uses a sarcastic but thoughtful argument to challenge Heather McNamara's suicidal thoughts and offers emotional support.
Lunges forward to strike Heather again, showing impulsivity and poor emotional control.
Questions the true purpose of the petition and refuses to sign despite pressure.
Slaps Heather Duke forcefully to express frustration.
Responds caustically and darkly jokes about harming Heather Duke when asked out by J.D.
Somberly steps forward to J.D., grabs his elbows, then pulls him gently for a kiss before spitting in his face and breaking up with him decisively.
Runs off after reading a threatening note, showing vulnerability and seeking to protect herself.
Whimpers at the sight of a Barbie doll hanging from a noose, showing emotional distress.
Takes the knife from J.D. and comments on its condition, showing concern for Heather's wellbeing.
Expresses empathy and fear that she could be the next victim.
Refuses to participate in forging a suicide note, standing up to J.D.
Races to stop J.D. from harming Heather Duke, crying out in distress.
Maniacally rattles the doorknob trying to open the locked door.
Stands in a corner with an 'Oh brother' look on her face during the funeral speech.
Hugs her cat J.F.K., showing tenderness towards a pet.
Rips down a hanging Barbie (symbolic act, possibly aggressive or rejecting superficiality).
Leans back in chair sweating, hesitates to smoke a cigarette given by J.D. (ambivalence or internal conflict).
Forces confrontation with J.D. to prevent bombing, tries to de-escalate by instructing him to put the bomb down and surrender.
Points a gun at J.D. to control the situation.
Lunges through the crowd knocking over disgruntled students to get to the boiler room.
Points gun at J.D. to stop him, asks how to turn off the bomb, urges him to help stop the impending violence.
Shoots gun at J.D.'s feet in a bid to gain control, showing desperation and determination to prevent harm.
Shoots J.D. to stop his violent plans and presses the red button twice to disable the bomb, saving lives.
Shows visible emotional distress and sheds tears after stopping the bomb, indicating empathy and sincere concern.
Walks away from the pep assembly and school crowd, opting for solitude and reflection.
Takes a cigarette and calmly faces the chaos after a bomb scare, showing no overt panic or alarm.
After the fake bomb scare, shows a slight smile basking in the sun’s rays, indicating a subtle appreciation for calm or relief.
Maintains composure and confidence when confronted by J.D. with an imminent bomb threat; responds calmly and with a sense of control ('Perfecto').
Stands her ground and faces chaos head-on when the bomb explodes, displaying no visible panic or confusion.
Takes calculated risks by confronting J.D. despite the danger and does not flee or act irrationally.
Displays a moment of verbal hesitation and uncertainty ('I thought I...you..'), indicating some internal confusion or emotional conflict.
Takes control of the situation by forcibly turning Heather Duke around and symbolically taking her red ribbon, asserting leadership with confidence.
Initiates a friendly and inclusive invitation to Martha to go to the video store and spend time together, showing social awareness and thoughtfulness.
Hands a note to Heather Chandler as part of a clique activity targeting Martha.
Responds with low key sarcasm about the famine fund effort and Africa.
Finishes the note and delivers it to Heather Chandler, navigating a social interaction with the Heathers smoothly.
Uses low key sarcasm to respond to Heather McNamara's naive question, demonstrating wit and social intelligence.
Apologizes sincerely to Betty Finn for missing her birthday party, shows embarrassment and ruefulness.
Gently laughs and interacts kindly with Betty Finn, acknowledging her innocent awe.
Cruelly bops away from Heather Duke as she is hurt by Heather Chandler's teasing.
Crashes into Betty Finn while distracted by James Deanesque guy, but immediately apologizes.
Glows at a photo of herself and Betty Finn, showing fondness for a friend from the past.
Complies with Heather Chandler pulling her away from Betty, does not avoid or defend the friendship, implies some reluctance.
Closes her eyes and shakes her head with a half-smile during Heather's sarcastic interaction, showing discomfort but remaining polite.
Glows at the photo showing a nostalgic moment, indicates emotional connection but is passive when Heather Chandler interrupts and leads her away, allowing the photo to fall unnoticed.
Closes her eyes and shakes her head with a half-smile at Heather Chandler's clipboard scenario, showing some internal skepticism or quiet dissent but does not directly challenge Heather.
Spins away from mirthful friends in disgust when Martha is ridiculed, makes eye contact with another disturbed person.
Participates in mocking Betty Finn with Heather Chandler.
Sarcastically comments on making a girl want to consider suicide.
Uses sarcastic wit to respond to Heather Chandler's mockery, showing quick thinking and verbal skill.
Recognizes the cruelty of the Heathers' actions toward Martha and visibly reacts with disgust, indicating emotional intelligence and moral awareness.
Engages in biting banter with Heather Chandler, using humor to deflect social pressure and maintain composure.
Appears to struggle with her position within the clique, showing ambivalence and hesitation.
Greets Jason Dean warmly and engages in playful conversation despite teasing from others.
Walks away abruptly when Heather Chandler interrupts her, showing some social restraint.
Asks J.D. a deliberately odd question to gauge his personality and thinking.
Walks away coolly from J.D. when Heather Chandler calls her, maintaining composure.
Flirts subtly with J.D., showing social awareness and confidence.
Ignores Heather McNamara's teasing and maintains focus on her interaction with J.D.
Recognizes that J.D. used blanks in the gun and realistically assesses the situation by minimizing the harm done, showing awareness and critical thinking.
Engages in light teasing about bleaching urine stains, showing social ease and wit in a tense environment.
Responds to Heather Chandler's comment about giving up on high school guys with 'Never say never,' showing cautious optimism and confidence.
Encourages Heather Duke with 'Give it up girl!' as Heather struggles with a shot.
Expresses amazement and enthusiasm at Heather Duke's successful shot ('Holy shit!') showing support and friendliness.
Picks up Heather Duke's ball and exuberantly throws it back toward the wickets.
Smiles and jokes with her dad, calling him an idiot playfully.
Picks up Heather Duke's ball and throws it back toward the wickets, showing engagement and energy.
Engages in light, witty banter with her dad, demonstrating social confidence and quickness.
Gives brief, non-committal answers about prom and plans, showing some uncertainty or lack of decisiveness.
Acknowledges she has to prepare for the party and plans her time accordingly.
Gently jokes to deflect tension and transitions to serious self-reflection about her social circle.
Openly acknowledges her dissatisfaction with her friends and social life, showing self-awareness.
Reflects on the superficiality of her friendships, indicating insight and critical thinking.
Shows emotional vulnerability after the party, frantically trying to write in her diary but struggles with a pen.
Responds politely to Brad's awkward attempt at conversation despite discomfort.
Shows silence or lack of engagement when Brad tries to suggest going to his room for a party.
Deals with Brad's awkward and superficial conversation assertively and sarcastically, indicating social awareness and verbal skill.
Unable to start her diary entry due to a pen malfunction, shows frustration but quickly switches pens and continues writing.
Does not participate actively in Brad’s attempts to escalate their interaction, remaining cool and somewhat detached.
Refuses drugs citing an anti-drug commercial as reason.
Calls out the hypocrisy about Phil Collins potentially drinking and driving.
Shows frustration and aggression by flinging cat off diary.
Laughs to herself while setting a flaming vodka cup on fire and throwing it out the window.
Laughs to herself after setting a flaming vodka cup on fire and tossing it out the window.
Refuses Brad's sexual advances firmly and yanks her coat to push him off the bed.
Storms into the hallway but slows when noticing attention, showing awareness but no direct confrontation.
Laughs to herself after tossing flaming vodka cup out the window, demonstrating quick thinking and slyness.
Maintains control in a tense moment by yanking her coat to make Brad slide off the bed, effectively asserting herself physically.
Stops storming out when she notices she's attracting attention, showing social awareness and self-control.
Engages in a heated exchange with Brad, standing her ground verbally and refusing to give in to his demands.
Shows frustration and anger but risks escalating conflict with Brad and Heather, potentially undermining her strategic position.
Feels awful and expresses regret for betraying Betty Finn, reflecting on her actions sincerely in her diary.
Retches and shows vulnerability in front of Heather Chandler.
Responds to Heather Chandler's insults with aggressive insults back.
Shows a willingness to stand up to Heather Chandler despite risk of social repercussions.
Expresses anxiety about social acceptance but tries to engage in the game with J.D.
Treats Heather's teen queen power plays as bullshit, showing skepticism but no hostility.
Shows willingness to be playful and companionable with J.D. despite her fears.
Uses her intelligence ironically to navigate social situations and make light of her academic potential.
Recognizes that killing Heather Chandler won't solve anything, showing practical judgment.
Engages in dark humor and risky conversations but maintains control and perspective.
Appears somewhat passive and compliant in the interaction with J.D., showing limited assertiveness.
Clearly understands the situation and confronts J.D. with confidence, suggesting they 'grow up, be adults, and die.'
Quietly informs J.D. that Heather Chandler skips trips to her grandmother's even when not hungover, demonstrating insight and knowledge.
Questions J.D.'s use of Pine-Sol for the hangover cure, recognizing its dangerous nature and speaking up assertively.
Acts enthusiastically while preparing a plan with J.D. to induce Heather Chandler to vomit, showing initiative.
Expresses fear and hesitation about poisoning someone, questions J.D.'s plan.
Mutters icily at J.D. and calls him 'jerk' while pouring milk and orange juice instead of poison.
Interacts playfully with J.D. (milk and orange juice joke), showing shared humor.
Glares down at the toxic containers and puts them away carefully, showing responsibility.
Says 'We both said a lot of things we didn't mean, last night.'
Shows a grudging smile.
Expresses disbelief and guilt over Heather Chandler's injury ('I just killed my best friend').
Enters Heather Chandler's bedroom with J.D. despite tension.
Stops joking about serious consequences, expresses concern about sending SAT scores to prison instead of college.
Objects to J.D.'s violent plan by differentiating between wanting someone out of life and causing harm.
Calms down J.D. and takes the initiative to write a suicide note to cover up the murder, showing some care about appearances and consequences.
Critiques the phrasing of the suicide note to make it more believable, showing attention to detail but also manipulation for deceptive purposes.
Lets out a laugh disguised as a sob when discussing Heather's suicide note.
Admits Heather was cool but cruel when asked to share feelings about her.
Lets out a disguised laugh during a serious discussion about Heather's suicide note, showing emotional complexity but poor social judgment.
Responds to the teacher's prompt with a brief, honest opinion about Heather being 'cool but cruel,' indicating self-awareness and the ability to engage thoughtfully.
Acknowledges the suicide note in horror and solemnly wears Heather's Swatch as a token of remembrance.
Responds to Heather Duke's rude comment about digestion with a sarcastic warning.
Turns on a shower and lets the water spray against her clothes, joining in on a playful and inclusive moment with other girls.
Exhibits a neutral, minimal verbal response ('Uh-huh') to Heather McNamara's comment about the act being warped.
Drops her broken watch without concern, ignores Heather McNamara's distress.
Interrupts and silences people on TV, mocks them and shows sarcasm.
Teases Courtney about Heather and questions her insincerity.
Greets J.D.'s father with a forced smile and attempts to shake his hand despite awkwardness.
Declines invitation to stay for dinner by giving a polite but distant reason about her mom's cooking.
Politely introduces herself to Fred Dean and attempts to shake his hand, maintaining a forced smile despite awkwardness.
Declines to stay for dinner with J.D. and his father, giving a reason related to her mother’s cooking, which shows social awareness and a polite exit.
Does not respond to the slight humiliation of the handshake being pulled away, managing to maintain composure.
Smiles and jokes with Dad about smoking, showing playfulness and ease in family interaction.
Weakly responds 'Right' to a potentially confrontational situation between Big Bud Dean and J.D., avoiding escalation.
Keeps conversation polite and cordial with parents, shows willingness to engage and be present.
Declines to be overly open about her feelings after Heather's suicide ('It was okay, I guess').
Mentions if they will meet the 'dark horse prom contender' with a noncommittal 'Maybe', avoiding sharing personal details or enthusiasm.
Says she needs to leave to prepare for the funeral, showing respect for social obligations but no expressed emotion.
Responds weakly when questioned by Big Bud Dead, showing a lack of assertiveness.
Smiles and jokes with her dad about his smoking habit, demonstrating social ease and wit.
Decides to leave to prepare for the funeral, showing time management and awareness of responsibilities.
Offers a non-committal answer when asked about the day after Heather's suicide, showing emotional reservation but possibly uncertainty.
Acknowledges her indirect involvement in Heather Chandler's death and expresses a desire for a better high school environment; shows self-awareness and reflection.
Responds casually to Heather McNamara about her evening plans, indicating social detachment rather than strategic social engagement.
Glares away Heather McNamara's smile at cow tipping, showing disapproval of mean-spirited behavior.
Makes a compassionate pause to look at Ram on top of a dispirited Heather McNamara.
Responds sarcastically to Kurt's 'sexual healing' comment with 'Yeah, right, asshole.'
Expresses discomfort and disapproval towards reckless drunk behavior and refuses to partake in cow tipping.
Observes the situation soberly and compassionately considers Heather McNamara's feelings.
Attempts to communicate to J.D. about the double date and her effort to help Heather despite difficult circumstances.
Offers to check on the lunchtime poll topic, greets others politely.
Clumsily hurries up the hill, gently tells J.D. not to smile in a certain way, shows mild concern.
Responds tersely or less solemnly to J.D.'s solemn gesture but still takes his hand.
Clumsily high heels it up the hill.
Comes into the yearbook workshop to check on the lunchtime poll topic and engages with the editors and yearbook girl.
Responds hesitantly and somewhat confused when asked about Heather's poems or artwork for the yearbook layout.
Throws a book at J.D. playfully and laughs.
Expresses revulsion and drops gun when J.D. talks seriously about real violence.
Clumsily extracts forged note and proudly shows it to J.D.
Proudly shares forged notes with J.D., engages in playful banter about serious topics.
Aims a gun at a cat in jest, but is quickly stopped by J.D.
Responds to J.D.'s discoveries with mild sarcasm but in a friendly manner.
Mock-seductively jokes with J.D. about heterosexuality, showing playful interaction.
Greets Kurt and Ram with forced cheerfulness in an awkward situation.
Directs Kurt and Ram to undress in circles to proceed with a plan involving a gun, indicating manipulation and coldness.
Calmly manages an awkward and tense situation by setting clear rules (circles, stripping) to control the interaction with Kurt and Ram.
Tucks a gun nervously in the back of her dress, indicating anxiety despite the controlled approach.
Uses forced cheerfulness when greeting Kurt and Ram, masking her true feelings to keep control of the situation.
Expresses guilt and pain over killing them, physically hurting herself with car lighter, denies wanting them dead.
Engages in argumentative back-and-forth with J.D., trying to resist his negative framing.
Responds to J.D.'s increasing provocation by covering ears and singing to block out his words.
Leans over to J.D. and makes a cynical comment about Mr. Kelly's love for his dead son while quietly laughing.
Notices a little girl mourning her brother and shows a visible reaction of discomfort and nausea.
Leans over to J.D. and makes a quietly witty comment at the funeral, showing social awareness and a sharp, subtle sense of humor.
Observes the little girl in Kurt’s jersey and experiences a shift in emotion from a smile to a nauseated grimace, indicating emotional sensitivity and awareness.
Responds deadpan 'Superb' to her mom about a tragic event, showing control and emotional restraint.
Drinks vodka alone and writes in diary about teen angst and deaths, showing self-reflection and emotional depth.
Mentions not being frightened by J.D.'s potential for harm, indicating a troubling tolerance or acceptance of dangerous behavior.
Fingers her bangs in an attempt at composure before stepping into the cafeteria to support a unifying moment among diverse students.
Swings her elbow into J.D.'s stomach to stop him from interrupting a special moment, asserting boundaries.
Agrees to participate in organizing a peer pressure prevention TV special involving all cliques.
Addresses J.D. with a sincere promise to work something out, showing willingness to cooperate.
Intercepts J.D.'s darker comments with a rebuke, indicating concern for positive interaction.
Agrees to take responsibility for organizing delegates from every clique for the suicide prevention special, indicating leadership and initiative.
Seeks J.D.'s agreement and support with uncertainty ('Won't we J.D.?'), showing a lack of confidence and dependence on others.
Expresses enthusiasm and eagerness when talking about redefining the high school experience, demonstrating engagement but possibly naivety.
Throws a framed picture at J.D. and calls him immature.
Sits down next to J.D. with dazed concern when he talks about his mother’s death.
Attempts to calm the situation by suggesting they settle down and mentioning Ms. Fleming’s chance to atone.
Decides to make the 'Ms. Pauline' thing work by creating lines of communication between cliques.
Sighs and slowly moves into a walking-out-the-door position, indicating hesitation or resignation rather than assertive action.
Expresses desire to show different kinds of people can get along and not be treated badly.
Gives Earl a Guest Pass tag to help him, expresses hope for change.
Violently pushes Heather Duke away and storms off after a minor prank.
Leaves a somewhat conciliatory message to Heather Duke, telling her she can wear her hair any way she wants.
Pauses and sighs deeply before calling Heather Duke, indicating reluctance and some sincerity.
Persuades Earl to participate in the TV show using thoughtful reasoning about social inclusion and change.
Violently pushes Heather Duke away and storms off after a brief moment of interaction.
Leaves a somewhat awkward and sarcastic voicemail on Heather Duke's answering machine.
Cringes and seems unsettled when David picks up the phone and mocks her while she is calling.
Knocks Betty's ball skillfully past Heather Duke without her noticing.
Questions Heather Duke about organizing the event and calls out her bad behavior.
Blows her own croquet shot after confronting Heather Duke.
Stares dumbfounded at the wicked homogeneity of the students and apologizes to Whitney James for the misleading nature of the event.
Stares dumbfounded at the wicked homogeneity of the students, uncomfortably steps onto the news set and apologizes for being misled about the gathering's diversity.
Bursts through the hand-holding circle and exits the stage, refusing to join the staged unity display.
Swaggers past a technician and considers manipulating the stage mechanism (console lever).
Rips off her pink armband in a moment of visible hesitation and freezes.
Sways back toward the technician's console after emotional devastation.
Slams the lever back down forcing the spinning circle of students to crash to the ground, disrupting the scene and taking decisive action.
Bursts through studio doors and pursues running barefoot through rough terrain and busy areas to reach her goal, showing physical determination and focus.
Returns home and summarizes her experience with sarcastic, insightful commentary demonstrating critical awareness of social dynamics and key players.
Leans against the wall with a melancholy smile acknowledging her difficult situation.
Slaps Heather Duke in the face after Heather mocks suicide attempt.
Says 'You're not funny' in response to Heather Duke's cruel comments about Martha Dumptruck.
Refuses to sign the petition knowing it's insincere and stands up to Heather Duke's pressure.
Slaps Heather Duke and confronts her about true friendship and her mean behavior.
Makes a dark, caustic joke about killing Heather Duke.
Firmly confronts J.D. about his sick psycho behavior and rebels against his attitude.
Flails and struggles but ultimately tries to communicate to J.D. that she's not on his side.
Gets angry and enraged when J.D. underlines Catcher in the Rye, but tries to express her feelings honestly.
Responds to Heather Chandler's prank with initial confusion but does not retaliate or lose composure.
Wakes up from a troubling dream sharply and takes immediate action by writing in her diary, putting on a monocle, and focusing on stopping J.D.
Expresses understanding of J.D.'s motives and plans to correct him, showing insight and resolve.
Undoes the noose and frees herself from a hanging, then reassures her frantic mother with a casual remark, hiding the gun to prevent panic.
Undoes a noose around her neck and escapes a suicide attempt, carefully covering the gun to avoid detection by her mom.
Feigns normalcy by casually greeting her mom after the attempt, masking her distress.

Freezes and hides inside her locker upon seeing J.D. approach, suggesting cautiousness and possible concern.

Freezes and hides inside her locker when she spots J.D. approaching, indicating cautious but possibly hesitant behavior.

Ignores Rodney's amiable attempts at conversation to move forward inquisitively through the crowd

Latches onto Rodney in a panic instead of relying on her own judgment.
Continues to inquisitively push forward and gather information despite anxiety.
Ignores Rodney's attempts at small talk, focusing on her own concerns.
Shows increasing sense of dread and tension while moving with the crowd without attempting to alter her course or take control.
